address.streetAddress: Ubicada en Villa De Bernal, No En Querétaro

127318146.name: Inspirational
127318146.author: a TripAdvisor user
127318146.reviewBody: The road to Bernal has greatly improved since the last time I visited in 2009.  Once you leave the freeway, it is mostly divided 4-lane.  It was easy to park close, above the base of the mountain.  Our group of 4 was able to hike up about 1/8, which took about 45 minutes.  Awesome views of the surrounding desert...seems to go on forever!  Beverage and souvenir stands line the sidewalk, until the sidewalk gives way to trail.  The town is also amazing.  While there, a parade with lots of music and dancing came by, adding to the already festive mood of this town.  La Pena can be viewed from almost anywhere in the town.

address.streetAddress: Ubicada en Villa De Bernal, No En Querétaro

126291145.name: Don\'t Miss
126291145.author: a TripAdvisor user
126291145.reviewBody: Be sure to get the 360 hike, circling the boulder. You have to get a guide (about $ 25 per person.

address.streetAddress: Ubicada en Villa De Bernal, No En Querétaro

125993630.name: Awesome day trip.
125993630.author: a TripAdvisor user
125993630.reviewBody: From Queretaro, take a 30 to 40 pesos cab ($3 US) to the Estacion de Autobus. Ask where the Fleche Azul counter is and purchase a ticket from QRO to Bernal for 36 pesos ($3 US). Finding the bus (out of about 100 vehicles) can be a bit challenging, so ask a friendly face where it is or look for the Fleche Azul bus with a laminated sign that says, "Bernal / Colon." The bus ride will take about 30 minutes or so to reach the town. You\'ll basically pass back near the airport, zoo, hit a few towns, before you start seeing more mountainous terrain and signs counting down to Bernal (25, miles, 17 miles, 14 miles, etc.). You\'ll know you\'re near Bernal when you see the "Pena" towering over on the left hand side of the bus. There are two stops near Bernal - one just outside the city proper and then one on the small highway that drops you off in the middle of restaurant row with gorditas stands and local shops. Cross the street, walk along the small highway, until you get to a corner where the BBQ / Barbacoa stand is sitting housed under an awning. Turn left and head down into the "centro historico," where you\'ll basically run into everything like Casa Tsayas (highly recommended, about 800 - 1000 pesos or $60 to $80 US) and other hotels (the square is not large at all). Give yourself about two to three hours to hike up and down the Pena (you\'ll get about two-thirds up before you\'ll need climbing gear). I wouldn\'t stop for a beer until after you\'re coming down, since the hike up will leave you sweating and out of breath. To catch the bus back to QRO, there\'s no bus counter. Basically, stand on the corner across from that BBQ / Barbacoa stand I mentioned (there might be a tour guide stand there too), and wait (up to one hour - yes, up to one hour!) for the Fleche Azul / Amarillo  to show up (find some shade, grab a gordita, and wait). You pay an attendant 36 pesos when you\'re seated on the bus. Sit back, sleep, and enjoy the ride back to the bus station. You can go to the taxi counter and get a metered ticked back into the Centro Historico of QRO for another 36 pesos (everything is 36 pesos!). I stayed the night in Bernal at Casa Tsayas (beautiful boutique hotel), though there\'s not much to do at night but dine in a local restaurant and listen to music while drinking cocktails. I wanted to take a wine tour to the nearby Ezequiel Montes (Freixenet, La Redonda, Azteca) but there were only two tour times (11 am and 3 p.m.), and it was noon - so I had the tour guide talk to a taxi driver (which happened to be dropping off a Mexican family, not many taxis otherwise) who drove me around and waited for me at the vineyards for 80 pesos ($8 an hour) - but I only recommend this if your Spanish is decent, it\'s the afternoon, and you\'re comfortable with the safety of the driver (I was). The ride out to the vineyards was 15 minutes and they\'re spaced about 5 minutes apart - La Redonda was my favorite though Freixenet was like "Wine" Disneyland with more to taste. Cheers, J

address.streetAddress: Ubicada en Villa De Bernal, No En Querétaro

125696299.name: QUERETARO-CADEREYTA-Vizarron
125696299.author: a TripAdvisor user
125696299.reviewBody: Flew into Mexico City and took a bus straight from the airport to San Juan del Rio.  They only have about 4 buses that leave every two hours directly from the airport.  It takes about 2 1/2 to get to San Juan bus station.  The bus is safe and a nice luxury bus.  From San Juan there is a bus that goes straight to Cadereyta (they leave about every 20 min.) that takes about and hour and 20 min.  Then from the bus station you can catch a taxi right outside to Vizarron for about $10 which takes about 20 minutes.  The Pe\u00f1a de Bernal is in between Cadereyta and Vizarron.  It takes about 20 minutes from Cadereyta to get to the Pe\u00f1a de Bernal..

121388627.name: 2nd Largest Monolith
121388627.author: a TripAdvisor user
121388627.reviewBody: A must see and hike in Queretaro!  Not too difficult as my 70 hr old uncle hiked with us.  His main workout schedule is walking. It was warm (even though) this week was one of the coolest this year (week after Thanksgiving).  Wear sunscreen and good hiking shoes.  We found on our way back down the monolith, which was more challenging and fun!  We did this adventure on our own rather than hiring a tour guide.  However, if I had to do it over again, I would hire EXXI Challenge to guide us.

120274213.name: Interesting
120274213.author: a TripAdvisor user
120274213.reviewBody: The town of Bernal is charming if rundown and a bit rustic.  The walk to the monolith is steep, not advised for the elderly, unfit or even those who have to push prams or carry toddlers as there is nothing at the end to interest the kids, except maybe the souvenir shop which sells ice creams.  If you have a spare afternoon to fill, I suppose it is worth seeing, the town is nice in the centre and there are things to look at and shops to browse in.

address.streetAddress: Ubicada en Villa De Bernal, No En Querétaro

118985713.name: Monolith, wool, food and craftsmanship... a real Mexican magic town!
118985713.author: a TripAdvisor user
118985713.reviewBody:
Very entertaining town. There are a lot of places to eat typical food from Queretaro. It is located about 45 minutes from Queretato City , capital of the state of Queretaro Mexico (and about 2 from Mexico City). Bernal is the town in which the third largest monolith in the world lies. From almost any point of the town can be seen this natural wonder. On special occasions, there are concerts on the monolith, and town parties celebrating their local Saint. However, not everything is related to the monolith. As Bernal is located in a very cold-wheater zone in Mexico, they made some of the best wool clothes, everything from light shirts to king-size blankets can be purchased there. Locals get the wool themselves from sheeps, dye them, and turn them into beatiful clothes (see one of my pics). 
When you're feeling hungry, there is a local market in which you can buy local food, with very local touch and taste, you'll never forget it! There are also a lot of local restaurants offering the same food, with great taste, too! 
If you need to walk a bit to digest your food you can always take a tour in the mask house, it is not big, but it is interesting, several masks can be found there, each one with a history of its own. Also take a walk while shopping some local craftsmanship.

Once you're done there, you can go back to Queretaro to see some historical buildings in which the History of Mexico as an independent country began.

address.streetAddress: Ubicada en Villa De Bernal, No En Querétaro

118163523.reviewBody: This lillte town is full of  traditions , u can walk the streets and ffind a lot of art , food ,churches , i love it .

600195392.name: The view and the wine
600195392.author: a TripAdvisor user
600195392.reviewBody: We went to Puerta del Lobo for the first time in October and i had such a great experience. The staff was very kind and told us that we could buy the bottle of wine at the store for a lower price and open it at the restaurant and they have delicious food I had the Caldereta, to be honest that was one of the best dishes I have tried in all my trips. Unfortunately this time I went there expecting it and oh surprise! They changed the menu! It was disappointing but I tried something else I don\u2019t remember the name but it was something about cordero and it was good but nothing special in comparison to the other dish. This time they didn\u2019t let us buy the wine in the store, we had to purchase it at the restaurant for 100 pesos more and if we wanted some to go they would discount those 100 pesos. The view at the restaurant in breathtaking and the staff is still very kind. Overall it is a good experience but I would love if they put some dishes back on the menu.

address.streetAddress: Calle Francisco i. Madero 10

669291185.name: Sitting in the Square
669291185.author: a TripAdvisor user
669291185.reviewBody: On a number of occasions during my holiday, I sat in the square and enjoyed the sites and sounds of historic El Centro Queretaro. What a treat to sip fresh juice and cinnamon coffee while watching a church processional or the children playing.  It was quite magical and even though I was alone, I felt very safe.

address.streetAddress: Calle Francisco i. Madero 10

662830944.name: Central, clean, and historically relevant
662830944.author: a TripAdvisor user
662830944.reviewBody:
This jardin (garden), used to be part of the nearby massive Templo San Francisco that used to cover many city blocks.  When it opened in 1874, it was named after the governor of the day, Benito Santos Zenea.  It has changed shape, style, and name over times and some older locals may still call it by one of its earlier names.  

Super clean garden with the perennial kiosk, this one from the Porfirian era with delicate French style.  It was especially beautiful when I visited because the purple jacaranda trees were in full bloom, the whole city covered with its magnificent color.  Queretaro doesn’t allow single-use plastic bags and in shows in that the city and its many parks are spotless.

Originally the location of Neptune’s statue which is said to have been used to make cannons in 1867 during the siege of the city – others claim it was moved to the Santa Clara Garden – take your pick.  It now hosts the daughter of Zeus, Goddess Hebe.  Surrounded by graceful swans, she is the carrier of ambrosia, a sign of youth or prime of life, of forgiveness and mercy.  What does that say about Queretaro? 

Enjoy sitting on one of the many benches in this peaceful oasis in the middle of the city.

address.streetAddress: Calle Francisco i. Madero 10

657929382.name: Pretty square
657929382.author: a TripAdvisor user
657929382.reviewBody: Lots of trees, vendors and flowers in the busy square in the historical center.    Surrounded by shops and restaurant as well as the Templo de San Francisco on th3 east side.

We were there in January so we were lucky enough to see the entire city decorated with light, projections, and this garden full of interpretations of the nativity, including devilish scenes, all in life size, animals, people, buildings everything.

The area is full of pastel- colored buildings and old historical places. There are lots of people shopping nearby. It is very safe, very clean, and it\'s family friendly.

330428023.reviewBody: Well, Qu\u00e9retaro knows ho to decorate its garden! In December they put a lot of religious full-scale representations (Nativity scene, Adam and Eve, Noah\'s ark, ..) and this is stunning! The garden is also green and full of flowers.

address.streetAddress: Calle Francisco i. Madero 10

330035854.name: Great for a stroll or dine or else
330035854.author: a TripAdvisor user
330035854.reviewBody: Its a must to walk by night when its all filled with light andbursting with life, have a drink or grab a bite, you\u00b4ll enjoy this place

address.streetAddress: Calle Francisco i. Madero 10

itemReviewed.name: Palacio de Gobierno Casa de la Corregidora

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

662320821.name: Sober neoclassical style in reaction against shameless baroque of the days
662320821.author: a TripAdvisor user
662320821.reviewBody:
Now Government Palace or Chief Magistrates’ House (Casa de los Corregidores), it also served as the Royal prison until not so long ago (in the west wing), horse stable, military barracks, seat of executive power and finally cradle of national independence.

The place where Miguel Domínguez and his wife Josefa Ortiz, Ignacio Allende, Juan Aldama, Miguel Hidalgo, and others first met to conspire against the Crown, the harsh beginning of the Mexican War of Independence.  The conspiracy was discovered, and things abruptly changed from there, but this is where the kernel, the seed of it began to germinate.

Today, visitors and locals can come to admire three beautiful murals, painted on fragile red travertine, illuminating and energizing the cold stern walls of the palace.  They are the amazing work of artist Víctor Cauduro (inaugurated in 2012) to recount a part of Mexico’s history.  Each mural, like a child in the womb, took nine months to paint.    

Mural 1 – National Independence.  
Mural 2 – Queretaro site and restoration of the republic.  
Mural 3 – Revolution and constitution of 1917.

itemReviewed.name: Palacio de Gobierno Casa de la Corregidora

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

657928990.name: Interesting guided tour
657928990.author: a TripAdvisor user
657928990.reviewBody: On the side of the Plaza de Independencia (Armas).   We took an interesting 20 minute guided tour with Casandra, which was in  Spanish only.   The interior courtyard has 3 large very recently painted (2015?) murals from major persons in Mexican history.    On the other side are government offices in the area which once housed a jail.   You can still see the tiny cell windows as well as the separate  male and female restraint areas for prisoners.

itemReviewed.name: Palacio de Gobierno Casa de la Corregidora

631403495.name: A good way to take a look to Mexican History
631403495.author: a TripAdvisor user
631403495.reviewBody: We just went there and we had a short but good tour.  What we love the most were the murals that had the principal character of important moments of Mexico\'s history such as the Independence, Revolution and the founding of Teotihuacan.

itemReviewed.name: Palacio de Gobierno Casa de la Corregidora

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

617114576.name: A trip into History...
617114576.author: a TripAdvisor user
617114576.reviewBody: I never imagined that stepping foot into a building could evoke such strong emotions. You are stepping into history. You can feel it in the well preserved walls and bricks that adorn this palace. The guided tour is highly recommended, as anyone approaching you is not only incredibly friendly but just so genuinely interested in sharing with you the history of the country, and their passion shows in their words! Great place to catch a little bit of shade too for half an hour while getting away from the sun.

itemReviewed.name: Palacio de Gobierno Casa de la Corregidora

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

600602012.name: Come , see how they White wash Mexican History
600602012.author: a TripAdvisor user
600602012.reviewBody: The place is of historical importance , now is a government building , it has 3 nice murals that totally white washed the Mexican independence Heroes. The bad part is that the tourist guides tell a conservative revisionist version of Mexico. As a Mexican historian all this make me really sad , the murals and the explanation wipe away very important information of my country. But Quer\u00e9taro state is one of the conservativism bastions  in Mexico.  From here you can take a leyends tours or eat in one of the expensive yet delicious restaurants.

itemReviewed.name: Palacio de Gobierno Casa de la Corregidora

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

550671405.name: Short but very fun visit
550671405.author: a TripAdvisor user
550671405.reviewBody: With Jorge as our guide, and walking only in the central patio, we had an amazing time re-visiting Mexico`s independence history.  This tour guide is more of an actor and he is extremely passionate about Mexico\'s history and heritage.   Great option and it will only take maybe 30 minutes.

itemReviewed.name: Palacio de Gobierno Casa de la Corregidora

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

531214060.name: Three nices murals to see
531214060.author: a TripAdvisor user
531214060.reviewBody: This place is conveniently located amidst the Queretaro sightseeing circuit, so you\'ll bump into it. It is worth entering to appreciate the three murals that reflect on Mexico\'s city. Worth listening to the guided tours to enhance your experience, otherwise estimate to spend about 5-10 minutes here max.

itemReviewed.name: Palacio de Gobierno Casa de la Corregidora

address.streetAddress: Plaza de Armas

673092068.name: Large church in the centre
673092068.author: a TripAdvisor user
673092068.reviewBody: This temple is a large church situated in the centre of the city, next to Jardin Zenea.  It is a nice church.

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

669042512.name: A nice first experience
669042512.author: a TripAdvisor user
669042512.reviewBody: This was our first time here to see this place.  It was quite impressive and ornate.  Beautiful architecture.

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

657930718.name: Large church by the Jardin Zenea
657930718.author: a TripAdvisor user
657930718.reviewBody: Have no idea why it was closed when we were there.    Large church on the east side of Jardin Zenea.   Pretty tiles on the dome.

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

655435215.name: Beautiful Franciscan Church
655435215.author: a TripAdvisor user
655435215.reviewBody: The Jesuits apparently controlled more property than the Franciscans in Mexico, but this church shows the Franciscan Order was no slouch. (February 2019)

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

618943585.name: Historic
618943585.author: a TripAdvisor user
618943585.reviewBody: If you love old churches this one fits the bill.  Well preserved with beautiful woods and stone.  Close to everything.  Worth a quick walk through.

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

369706947.name: Another impressive church
369706947.author: a TripAdvisor user
369706947.reviewBody: It\'s right in the center of the histical center, so you should certainly walk in.  And be sure to walk all the way around the interior

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

340431851.name: nice and old
340431851.author: a TripAdvisor user
340431851.reviewBody: It was in front of the hotel so we went. It is a nice preserved place. It has a Franciscan decor, meaning not as churrigueresco as other churches in Mexico, but it was a nice spot to see.

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

313282904.name: Old world charm and sightseeing
313282904.author: a TripAdvisor user
313282904.reviewBody: Eye-popping building with majestic architecture.  On the edge of a plaza across the street.  This is a beautiful church and further up Corregidor is the stop for the tour trolley.

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

239533944.name: Tallest Queretaro landmark
239533944.author: a TripAdvisor user
239533944.reviewBody: This is a good place to visit. The architecture is impressive. They have started lighting up the church for Xmas already.\nWe did not go inside, but presume that the interior would be quite impressive as well. Do not miss it. The Zocalo is nearby, with many restaurants.

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

236367663.name: Nice church
236367663.author: a TripAdvisor user
236367663.reviewBody: Great church honoring Sait Francis.  Beatiful and very well maintained.  Nice organ on Sunday services.  Worth to visit.

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

226369208.name: Imposing Presence on the Jardin
226369208.author: a TripAdvisor user
226369208.reviewBody: This Cathedral enjoys a prominent location right in the heart of centro Queretaro.  From the number of people we saw entering, it seems to be a popular place.

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

217231655.name: Maybe the first thing ever to stop me in my tracks :)
217231655.author: a TripAdvisor user
217231655.reviewBody: I\'m a 31 year old guy and this was the first time I\'d walked in and seen a church decorated with such detail and intricacies.  Maybe it was because it was the first time, or because it was early evening and starting to quiet down, or because it was my first night ever in a place or town like this; but it literally topped me in my tracks and made tears well up.  \n\nI visited nearly all the churches in Queretaro that week, and each was it\'s own sight to see.  This one remains my favorite as its the only one I had such an intense and overwhelming experience seeing (assuming because it was the first) but I\'d recommend checking out each one.  They\'re always just a quick stop and look; but still worth taking the time to try and park and walk around.  Always shops and a plaza near any church in Queretaro, including this one.  So you can always roll it up into a half hour of shopping too.

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

203324908.name: Interesting Church
203324908.author: a TripAdvisor user
203324908.reviewBody: The church is interesting with plenty of statues. It is not as colonial as the other main churches but one can sense its historical importance.\n\nRMS

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

192965269.name: Excellent Cathedral ...
192965269.author: a TripAdvisor user
192965269.reviewBody:
Excellent Cathedral ... right next to the Art Museum in downtown QRO ... 

It is important for the patron saint but is also a very well kept cathedral ... 

Good for a quick stop.

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

175139849.name: Nice church, and monsatry
175139849.author: a TripAdvisor user
175139849.reviewBody: Nice old church, with an attached monastery which dates back to the 1500\'s. Take the tour inside the monastery where the guide (English) will show you the thorn three (thorns in the shape of a cross) and the old ruins; with aqueduct-ed water all around.

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

156028859.name: Gorgeous
156028859.author: a TripAdvisor user
156028859.reviewBody: This is such a beautiful church; actually my favorite in the city; the light inside the church is so lovely; I make it a point to visit churches and this one is worth a visit

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

154360861.name: Beautiful Colonial Church
154360861.author: a TripAdvisor user
154360861.reviewBody: This is one of the main churches in Old Downtown Queretaro.  It is very beautiful and always busy.  Located on one of the main squares of town.  There are many people selling their goods around the square as well as many wonderful restaurants.

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

142540239.name: An interesting place.
142540239.author: a TripAdvisor user
142540239.reviewBody: This place has several interesting details that may escape the viewer. Even so, the place itself gets a bit lost in the middle of the city and may pass as just-another-church. One of the quirks is that by the pedestrian zone side, there\u2019s a fake door, painted on the wall for you not to look twice. This building shows the pass of the time and all the modifications suffered through the centuries. The temple used to be part of a cloister; the other part of it is occupied by the regional museum which also is an interesting place to visit.

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

140390603.name: Just one of many but worth it
140390603.author: a TripAdvisor user
140390603.reviewBody: Templo de San Francisco, is just one of many churches in Queretaro but you do not need to be religious to appreciate its beauty.

address.streetAddress: 5 de Mayo / Corregidora

673312650.name: Nice but not so impressed
673312650.author: a TripAdvisor user
673312650.reviewBody: The place is nice , having an interesting story behind and an nice collection of old furniture and canvases. I was not so impressed. The view from the top is beautiful and arriving there I found "Jardin del arte" which impressed me more.

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

657930338.name: Nice collection of 18th and 19th century furniture and decorations
657930338.author: a TripAdvisor user
657930338.reviewBody: 45 pesos to enter.    There are 2 separate short movies in English or Spanish describing the mystery of the couple who lived here.   Impressive collection of 18th and 19th century furniture and decorations.    You can also climb up a spiral staircase to get a good 360 degree view of the city.    The very nice lady at checkin said we could use our tickets to get in to other houses in the area for no additional charge (although we didn\u2019t and don\u2019t know which houses would qualify).

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

618764762.name: Portrait of XIX century life
618764762.author: a TripAdvisor user
618764762.reviewBody: I love visiting houses that portray lifestyle of an era, it helps me picture history more vividly, so if you like that to then I highly recommend this museum. Of course, it is a portray of a wealthy family but in true manner of old mexican soap opera \u201clos ricos lloran tambi\u00e9n\u201d there is a tragic story behind. Go and find out what it is about :)

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

617123226.name: Interesting museum to visit
617123226.author: a TripAdvisor user
617123226.reviewBody: An hour of your time would be sufficient to visit this former house with its mystery, showed in a movie.

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

567433516.name: Second time around
567433516.author: a TripAdvisor user
567433516.reviewBody: I love wondering through this house and the story of the woman who lived her.  Intrigue it was. Won\'t give it away but I must to see the furniture and listen to the story.  I lived in Germany for 10 years and lots of heavy furniture in those houses.

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

537637098.name: Fun and spooky and worth a visit?Especially around the Dia de los Muertos time
537637098.author: a TripAdvisor user
537637098.reviewBody: Centrally located in el centro so easy to find (with map app).  A very nice and itneresting presentation on how the wleathy of the 19th century lived in  QRO.  Interesting display of period furniture in wealthy MX and a wonderful story of what happened in this very home.... murder and mayhem and mystery.... And for those of us with very weak Spanish skills,,,,,, there are videos presenting the story in English which I greatly appreciated and is quite a rarity in QRO overall.

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

536766064.name: historic
536766064.author: a TripAdvisor user
536766064.reviewBody: very interesting especially for tourists, was amazed to find it tucked away, lovely to be able to just walk around

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

482665083.name: Unusual site
482665083.author: a TripAdvisor user
482665083.reviewBody: On a quiet side street, this museum is different from the other sites in the colonial center -- this one shows how upper class in Queretaro lived in the 19th century.  Beautiful furnishings, ceramics, paintings and more.  The other unusual aspect is the story of the Zacatecan, who murdered her husband.  Lively videos explain the tawdry tale.  Worth a visit.

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

437924100.name: Interesting way to spend an hour
437924100.author: a TripAdvisor user
437924100.reviewBody: The house itself has been beautifully restored, and each room has beautiful collections.  I really enjoyed looking at the furniture and the glassware, and the view over Quer\u00e9taro from the lookout is stunning.

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

428246228.name: History and legends...
428246228.author: a TripAdvisor user
428246228.reviewBody: Here you can learn about the legend of this house while you learn more about the daily life od mexican people in XIX century

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

418892286.name: Good place to visit on a rainy day.
418892286.author: a TripAdvisor user
418892286.reviewBody: Old home with a very interesting history. Great period furniture. Unfortunately not wheelchair accessible. I would recommend it for people interested in learning about this period of Mexican history.

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

355425537.name: A charming little place
355425537.author: a TripAdvisor user
355425537.reviewBody: Fairly organised and regulated for a small place. The entry ticket includes a part guided tour in Spanish followed with relevant videos. If you\'re a history buff and like connecting with the characters who once lived there - you\'d love it!

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

349000960.name: worth a peek if time permits
349000960.author: a TripAdvisor user
349000960.reviewBody: Allegedly the site of an 18th-century crime of passion (luridly recounted in an explanatory video), the Casa de la Zacatecana is primarily interesting as an intact example of a colonial residence of the period. Each of the patio-facing rooms on two floors has been furnished in a different historical style, though few of the objects on display are original to the house. Among the most interesting is a scroll depicting the history of the world on parallel national tracks. For those with a liking for the material culture of a bygone age, it\'s worth an idle hour.

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

326585042.name: Interesting and Mysterious
326585042.author: a TripAdvisor user
326585042.reviewBody: They tell you the spooky story about the people that used to live there. The museum if full of antiques and old furniture, your not allowed to take photos unless you pay extra. My boyfriend didn\'t find it interesting, but I love to see antique and vintage things, so I enjoyed the museum.

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

303908935.name: An interesting house full of beautiful art objects
303908935.author: a TripAdvisor user
303908935.reviewBody: I found this beautiful house interesting to visit and the videos of the Zacatecana legend were entertaining enough but the price seemed a bit high for what was offered (maybe teenagers should be free then it would be OK).  It takes about 45 minutes to view the two videos and visit the twelve rooms. There are many beautiful art objects but most pieces are hard to appreciate because you can only look at them from the entrance to the room.

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

290912468.name: Queretaro Gem
290912468.author: a TripAdvisor user
290912468.reviewBody: A must visit museum. Amazing variety of artifacts and the house and family who occupied it have an interesting history too. Lovely architecture and full value for money.

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

275401925.name: Fun and worth it
275401925.author: a TripAdvisor user
275401925.reviewBody: Unexpected. Good price. Interesting story and lovely antiques. Guys. Just go. This was fun and worth the time and price. Agree that this place SPOOKY too.

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

254876197.name: Excellent
254876197.author: a TripAdvisor user
254876197.reviewBody: this was really a house, is very nice and misterious, if you ask the story to your guide you will see you will love.. is very nice the house already and you are in the center so you can visit so much more things

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

214676946.name: Spooky!!
214676946.author: a TripAdvisor user
214676946.reviewBody: As a museum this house is so so, but for sheer spookiness it can\'t be beat!   The two skeletons that you can see through a plexiglass covered opening in the floor really brought home the reality of the murder(s) that took place here.  Raised the hair on the back of my neck.  I\'m glad we went....not something you see every day, nor is the story a common one (thank goodness!).  Well worth the price of admission in my opinion.

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

199585242.name: Had higher expectations
199585242.author: a TripAdvisor user
199585242.reviewBody: Didn\'t love it at all. It was pretty old, not perfectly maintaned. The lights should dimm when you entered in the room however the system was not working. The TV\'s used to present the crime plot were pretty old. Doesn\'t worth the visit!

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

188736120.name: Historical House with Artifacts
188736120.author: a TripAdvisor user
188736120.reviewBody: If you enjoy a mysterious legend and have a fancy for antiques, this museum is worth stopping by. You do have to pay an entrance fee and a small fee to take photos, but the house is full of furniture and collectibles from hundreds of years ago. It also has a nice lookout point on top where you can see Quer\u00e9taro for miles.

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

164618538.name: Fascinating Home
164618538.author: a TripAdvisor user
164618538.reviewBody: For those interested in history and decor this former private residence is a great place to see what life was like in Mexico in the mid 1800\'s.

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

149744237.name: Not quite so grand.
149744237.author: a TripAdvisor user
149744237.reviewBody: This museum has all sorts of antique furniture in it, but none of it pertains to the murder mystery that happened in the home. The home itself is beautiful architecturally. The staff seem more intent on making you pay for things like your camera than showing the videos about the murder mystery.

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

136146496.name: An old House enchanted with mystery.
136146496.author: a TripAdvisor user
136146496.reviewBody:
La Casa de la Zacatecana, now a museum,  is an old house with reminders of what Mexico was like centuries ago. One of the most popular legends in the house dates from the 17th century and its about a woman originally from the state of Zacatecas, who asked one of the servants of the house to kill her husband. Once the murder took place, the woman later killed the servant herself in the house so he wouldn't talk of the event. It is said that she buried the bodies in the stables. There are a pair of human remains that you can see from the patio of the house. The woman was later found dead outside the house and her murder remains a mystery to this day. There are some who say her ghost can be seen around the house.
In that house, they also started the paperwork  for the second Emperor of Mexico Maximiliano de Habsburgo's trial, who was later executed with other two generals: Tomás Mejía and Miguel Miramón in El Cerro de las Campanas. Miramon's body was embalmed in one of the rooms inside this house. 
If you are familiar with Mexico's history, you will find it interesting. If you want to appreciate old Mexican Art in downtown Querétaro, this is a good place to start. Each room features a great collection of antiques from different times in history. 
The entrance is pretty cheap (less than $3.00 USDLLRS) and contributes to restore some of the old paintings and the maintenance of the house.  I would really recommend it if you want to get to know a piece of Mexico.

address.streetAddress: Independencia No. 59, Centro Historico Entre Luis Pasteur y Dr. Río de la Loza

673315283.name: Amazing architecture
673315283.author: a TripAdvisor user
673315283.reviewBody: The place worth to be seen for its amazing architecture first. Them, there are some interesting paintings displayed.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

658846993.name: Gorgeous building provides lovely rooms for wandering and looking at Art
658846993.author: a TripAdvisor user
658846993.reviewBody: Think quality large art works rather than lots of pieces. The museum is free to wander into. Many of the signs telling about the architecture are in both Spanish and English. There are large high-ceiling rooms with a few stunning permanent works in each room and then other smaller galleries with revolving shows chocked full of pieces if the featured artist is prolific. Spend as long as you want, or just wander in for a quick look.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

657926904.name: Fantastic architecture
657926904.author: a TripAdvisor user
657926904.reviewBody: I was amazed by the architecture particularly the interior courtyard.  Building was originally a monastery built between 1731 and 1748.    Museum displays mostly earlier paintings  from the 16th and 17th centuries as well as modern works.    For me, th3 highlight was the interior courtyard architecture - not the artwork.  Free to enter.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

655399758.name: Art and Architecture
655399758.author: a TripAdvisor user
655399758.reviewBody: The collection includes both classic pieces as well as contemporary.  As others have said, the courtyard itself is worth the price of admission, which is free by the way.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

648400845.name: Interesting special exhibits
648400845.author: a TripAdvisor user
648400845.reviewBody: Only special exhibits were on display. It\'s worth a visit just to see the incredible interior architecture, which dates back to the mid-1700s. The special exhibits were thought-provoking and original, fun and disturbing.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

643077276.name: FANTASTIC!
643077276.author: a TripAdvisor user
643077276.reviewBody: A total surprise as we did not know about the museum so did not plan on visiting but decided to stop in as we passed by. Can\u2019t say enough good things and highly  recommend it!

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

595974752.name: Impressive courtyard
595974752.author: a TripAdvisor user
595974752.reviewBody: The courtyard was the highlight for us. We walked through several exhibits and also enjoyed them. Recommend

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

581526516.name: Architectural gem...
581526516.author: a TripAdvisor user
581526516.reviewBody: The museum of the arts is an architectural gem, the art on display varies and as always with art beauty is in the eye of the beholder... so no doubt you will find pieces that appeal and others that you wonder how they found their way into a museum.  There is no set fee, but donations are requested and very much worthwhile.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

570870734.name: Unique architecture and excellent exhibition
570870734.author: a TripAdvisor user
570870734.reviewBody: No visit to Quer\u00e9taro is complete without the Museo de Arte. The courtyard is breathtakingly beautiful as is the entire architecture of this building. What is more, they come up with interesting contemporary art worth seeing. When I went works by Pedro Meyer were on display, a spanish-mexican photographer I had never heard of but whose pictures were quite stunning.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

566746050.name: Surprise Reaction
566746050.author: a TripAdvisor user
566746050.reviewBody: I cannot remember breaking into a deep belly laugh in a museum, but I did here.  The artist clearly had a twisted sense of humor.  One painting showed some blurry figures in the fog.  The translated title was Looking for the Chimera.  There was also a slide photo exhibit of seedy slice of life New York City which held my attention for ten minutes.  Beautiful building, donation only.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

547744377.name: Permanent collection only okay, visiting and rotating exhibitions range from mediocre to excellent.
547744377.author: a TripAdvisor user
547744377.reviewBody: It\'s an attractive building smackdab in the UNESCO centro, between two fantastic churches, and various gardens, really an exquisite location.  But they need a rich benefactor to upgrade their permanent collection.  It\'s worth a visit, but really hit or miss as to whether the non-permanent exhibits will be any good.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

544815049.name: I enjoyed this musem
544815049.author: a TripAdvisor user
544815049.reviewBody: I enjoyed the collection here of both modern and classic art. The courtyard was amazing as well. I spent an hour or two looking through the collection. Very convenient in the center in the middle of everything.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

476578173.name: Worth a visit
476578173.author: a TripAdvisor user
476578173.reviewBody: We popped here for a visit. Free entry. The building is worth a look even if you aren\'t bothered about the art. The japanese art made of threads was spectacular but the older paintings upstairs were not my taste. Follow the arrows around and explore. A rich history and the buildings had many uses over the years. Pop in and have a look. Only took us 30 minutes to see everything.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

476085046.name: In my opinion overrated
476085046.author: a TripAdvisor user
476085046.reviewBody: If I had paid I would have felt cheated.  Interesting building but marginal art.  It is worth going to take a look at the beautiful building.  I imagine they change the exhibits so we may just have gotten one of the more boring ones.  However, art is very personal so to others it might be wonderful.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

449711387.name: Stunning!
449711387.author: a TripAdvisor user
449711387.reviewBody: A remarkable building and courtyard with superb detail! The galleries featured a mix of art -- mostly contemporary. There is also an excellent bookstore attached.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

447002604.name: Great museum
447002604.author: a TripAdvisor user
447002604.reviewBody: My hotel was close to this museum so one day I decided to visit it.\nIt is wonderful museum ... pity it did not have enough time to enjoy it. I recommend you to reserve min 2 hours for visit of this museum.\nI was very surprised that such great museum was for free.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

424363308.name: Very satisfying!
424363308.author: a TripAdvisor user
424363308.reviewBody: This beautiful museum is housed in a former Augustine monastery which is worth the visit just to see it. We saw 2 beautiful exhibits. One presenting Famous artists of Mexico up to the last century. A beautiful collection. \n\nWe also discovered a new (to us), talented Mexican artist, Wuero Ramos.  After leaving the museum we bought a book of his paintings in the incredible bookstore next door with a huge assortment of art books.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

399514628.name: Beautiful Building; Average Collection
399514628.author: a TripAdvisor user
399514628.reviewBody: If for no other reason visit the Museum of Arts just to see in interior courtyard. Truly magnificent! It will be one of the best interiors you see in all of Mexico. We visited on a Saturday afternoon and it was FREE. If you wanted to take photos, there was a $15MEX charge (extremely reasonable). It is not a large museum! There is an interesting collect, albeit small, of contemporary art. It was still interesting enough to capture the attention of my 10 year old grandson. As it is just a block off Madero Street in the historical center of Queretaro, it is well worth a short visit so as to see the building.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

398421836.name: Lovely building , interesting modern art
398421836.author: a TripAdvisor user
398421836.reviewBody: Worth a visit for the art and the architecture\nLocated in the centro.  Tuesday is free entry. Although the entry fee is minimal\n

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

393222554.name: Top museum in Quer\u00e9taro
393222554.author: a TripAdvisor user
393222554.reviewBody: Housed in the former Convent of San Agust\u00edn, this museum should be required visit when you go to Quer\u00e9taro. The building alone is worth the visit; the views from all angles of the interior patio are astonishing (pay the 15 pesos fee for the use of the camera). The permanent collection is wonderful (do not miss the rooms of the religious colonial paintings on the second floor), and the temporary exhibits are always interesting.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

390561507.name: The building worth the visit
390561507.author: a TripAdvisor user
390561507.reviewBody: Maybe the exhibitions are not spectacular, but the building would worth your visit to this place. Beautiful and breathless architecture. Everything is in a very good condition.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

357998851.name: Great visit, free entrance!
357998851.author: a TripAdvisor user
357998851.reviewBody: We visited this museum and I thought it was worth the visit. The entrance was free and it had a rich baroque architecture which; like others reviewers mentioned it used to be a monastery during the New Spain. It had a rich art collection borrowed from Carlos Slim and couple of more art collectors. However, the only down size was the lack of information in English :(   They offered an audio tour for free, but only in Spanish. They also charged us few pesos to take pics, which we didn\'t mind paying. They were very strict and didn\'t allow us to take pics, so watch out. The bathrooms were very clean.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

356688644.name: All epochs represented
356688644.author: a TripAdvisor user
356688644.reviewBody: This free museum is housed in a beautiful ex-convent, with wonderful architecture and decoration in the cloisters. The works are all visual art, paintings, and represent many epochs. The most delicate pieces are in air conditioned rooms, which might be a relief to visitors on a hot day.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

352381844.name: Great Beauty
352381844.author: a TripAdvisor user
352381844.reviewBody: The building alone is worth the trip and they have a good permanent collection.  And interesting new art.  Lovely spot.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

349002518.name: a work of art in and of itself
349002518.author: a TripAdvisor user
349002518.reviewBody: Located in a repurposed former Augustine monastery, Queretaro\'s Museum of Arts is as notable for its splendid colonial architecture as for its impressive collections. The courtyard alone brims with allegorical figures and gargoyles, perfectly suited to the galleries of exquisite sacred art within. The scope of the collection is truly impressive, boasting not only major Mexican works, but also those of the European grand masters. Temporary exhibitions give equal space to cutting-edge contemporary art, and there are regular performances and live events. This is one of the gems in a gem of a city.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

342516112.name: A collection of art
342516112.author: a TripAdvisor user
342516112.reviewBody:
In this museum you will see any kind of art being exhibited, plays, cinema, paintings, etc.

Here I have seen and witnesed the most scarry things to the most beautiful.

they say that at night there are spirits going around as it used to be part of the convent of the Pies descalzas.

It is a must go before checking the program of course, every week there is something different going on.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

337109980.name: Amazing courtyard and strong collection.
337109980.author: a TripAdvisor user
337109980.reviewBody: The permanent collection was impressive, as was a temporary exhibit with pieces from three great Mexico City museums.  If you are not into art museums, go for the courtyard which is an architechtural gem.  View it from both floors.  Admission is free.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

317626123.name: Extraordinary building, great collection, good exhibits, prime location. Must see
317626123.author: a TripAdvisor user
317626123.reviewBody:
The ex-Convent of St Augustine, where this museum is located, is one of the best Colonial buildings in the whole country, and among the super top in Queretaro. 

There is some fun in the architecture: the cariatids at the top of the central patio walls have differing hand gestures, carrying codes used by the Augustine monks and also redolent of ancient mudras.

The integration of decorative elements, the pure blue skies and brilliant sun, and the proportions of the arches make this central patio an outstanding place to be.

The museum's permanent collections hold remarkable art from the Baroque period and paintings from other ages, among the most notable in Mexico. Temporary exhibits combine contemporary art and all other periods, often with exceptional pieces. The museum is spacious and generally well lit. Staff is friendly and unobtrusive.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

316586135.name: A Must See
316586135.author: a TripAdvisor user
316586135.reviewBody: I just love this place. It is such an incredibly beautiful building and that alone would be enough but the exhibitions were fascinating. I was surprised at how long I spent looking at the exhibitions and just wandering around the building taking photographs. It is a place I will never forget and will return to next time I am in Queretaro - which cannot be soon enough for this traveler!

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

293882400.name: amazing building; if you are lucky you will get a great exhibition
293882400.author: a TripAdvisor user
293882400.reviewBody: The buiding in itself is worth the visit, with an amazing central courtyard. You should spend some time just admiring the architecture. Then you can enjoy the permanent and temporary exhibitions.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

285807438.name: One of the nicest museums in Mexico
285807438.author: a TripAdvisor user
285807438.reviewBody: I\'ve visited twice, with different temporary exhibitions each time.  Exhibits have been of interesting, good to great modern Mexican artists, with works well chosen and well displayed.  Reasonably priced entry and a beautiful courtyard.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

259655191.name: Variety of Art
259655191.author: a TripAdvisor user
259655191.reviewBody: Today, being unexpectedly rainy, it was a perfect museum day. The Queretaro Museum of Art didn\'t dissapoint. Though I\'m not a particularly avid modern art fan, I enjoyed the brilliant colors and humor of the works of Oswaldo Sagastegui and also the new collection of paintings of Pope Francis by the Argentine painter, Mercedes Farina. Of course, there are many other styles of art from different eras as well, not to mention the beautiful building itself, a former convent.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

259006376.name: Beautiful old Convent
259006376.author: a TripAdvisor user
259006376.reviewBody: Had a local artist on display plus their own collection. The architecture was incredible. We also attended a night reception with a violin echoing through he courtyard.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

249843016.name: My favorite building
249843016.author: a TripAdvisor user
249843016.reviewBody: This museum is located in the most beautiful building. The patio is fully renovated and has an amazing fountain in the middle. We stayed a whole hour just admiring the different sculptures in the patio. The collection is small and not very impressive, but it is worth the visit.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

247247159.name: Building is amazing, collections presented are so so
247247159.author: a TripAdvisor user
247247159.reviewBody: You\'ll enjoy walking through such amazing building, however the collections downstairs is not at the level of the environment. The photos don\'t look professional, aren\'t well presented. The regional museum is a million times better.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

241176661.name: Well Worth the Visit
241176661.author: a TripAdvisor user
241176661.reviewBody: This museum was definitely worth the visit.  The entrance fee was $30 Pesos and $15 Pesos additional if you wish to take pictures inside.  At first I thought this odd, but once you start walking into the building you notice the exceptional architecture.  Needless to say, we went back to pay the additional funds.  The museum has a variety of artifacts from modern to religious.  Overall, it was well worth the time to visit.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

237769065.name: Modern art in a classic entourage
237769065.author: a TripAdvisor user
237769065.reviewBody: Te museum of arts in Queretaro is a very beautiful XVII century building of baroque style with a superb patio that in itself makes the visit worth. The museum is a dynamic organisation that sets frequent modern arts shows and the contrast between baroque and moderna arts is always positively striking. The library has many of the CONACULTA publications that are very interesting.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

214001254.name: Awesome mix of old (Mexican Baroque) and new (national contemporary artists)
214001254.author: a TripAdvisor user
214001254.reviewBody: Gorgeous facility, laid out nicely, with a pleasing mix of old and new offerings- Highly recommended

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

201981186.name: Colonial Art & Architecture
201981186.author: a TripAdvisor user
201981186.reviewBody:
While in Queretaro, we visited The Museum of Art April 10th and found it to be outstanding. The museum has one of the great collections of colonial art . It was the former convent of San Augustin 
and the colonial architecture is also worth the visit.One had to pay an admission price of 30 pesos about less than three dollars. They also had a exhibits of modern art. The book store is worth looking at.

RMS

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

200960276.name: Excellent Museum
200960276.author: a TripAdvisor user
200960276.reviewBody: My wife and I recently visited Queretaro Mexico.  Beyond the fact that the city is beautiful, exceptionally clean and friendly, we also wanted to recommend the Museum of Arts. Such a beautiful setting and wonderful Museum.  It should be on your list of places to visit in central Mexico!

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

198541508.name: Beautiful building with interesting collection of art
198541508.author: a TripAdvisor user
198541508.reviewBody: The museum building is gorgeous--visiting to enjoy the building is almost enough.  The collection is strong with regional artists who are worthy of remembrance.  Definitely a can\'t miss if you are in Queretaro.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

192965055.name: Excellent museum ...
192965055.author: a TripAdvisor user
192965055.reviewBody: This museum plus the "Museo de la Ciudad" which is a more modern art museum are both excellent examples of how QRO has established itself as a wonderful tourist destination in central Mexico.\n\nBoth of these museums especially the "Museo de la Ciudad" are a must if you like art and are visiting QRO.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

179726494.name: 25 years of excellence in art
179726494.author: a TripAdvisor user
179726494.reviewBody:
Last week we went to an art opening at the museum and the celebration of its 25th anniversary. The doors opened at 7:00 PM and the patio soon filled with about 200 plus guests. There were the usual speeches from museum and city dignitaries. These were not too long winded and the people who make a museum like this possible really should be recognized.

The entertainment started with Flamenco dancing. Around the fountain in the center of the main patio stood four dancers. Each dancer in turn performed Flamenco unaccompanied by music. Each dancer performed in turn around the fountain. It was very dramatic. The next performance was a free style emotively interpretative performance of music by a man playing a synthesizer. I am always amazed at these types of musical presentation because they are repeatable, but I don’t know how. The dancers returned to a stage in the corner of the patio for their final performance to music. This time the full ensemble of 8 or more dancers were performing. They were beautiful and technically elegant.

The gallery of new art was then opened upstairs. The name of the presentation was Sensaciones Compartidas which means shared sensations. I would describe it as interactive art. Many of the pieces were meant to be touched as well as seen. I did get into trouble at one of the displays. It was a solitary picture of a pan dulce with a tray of the same sweet bread directly below the photo. The viewer was invited to take a piece of the pan, which I did. It was now about 8:30 and I was starving so I took a bight of the art. That was a mistake. The museum food police immediately instructed that eating inside the gallery was forbidden so I rushed outside to finish my treat.

Queretaro knows how to throw a party. After the gallery had been open for a while the museum served wine and hors d’oeuvres to the guests. Red or white wine was served in tall wine glasses. The waiters who served the appetizers were mobbed with each appearance. Evidently, the other patrons were as hungry as I was but at least they were in the common area away from the art.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

174293654.name: very nice
174293654.author: a TripAdvisor user
174293654.reviewBody: The building is amazingly beautiful, as many buildings in Quer\u00e9taro. You can also have a nice glimpse of local and national art (painting, photography, etc.).

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

169800963.name: Beautiful building
169800963.author: a TripAdvisor user
169800963.reviewBody: This is one of those cases where the building is as good a work of art as the exhibits it holds. The museum has regular exhibits, a beautiful patio, and a decent permanent exhibition of secular and colonial art.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

151744765.name: A must-see if in Queretaro
151744765.author: a TripAdvisor user
151744765.reviewBody:
Queretaro is one of my favourite cities in Mexico. Even though it is growing fast and is surrounded by commercial and industrial areas the historical centre is just so elegant and beautiful.

Each time I visit I never fail to go to the art museum in spite of the fact that I'm not particularly into museums!  For me the architecture of the patio is astounding: everywhere you look there are curious sculptured figures, all of which have symbolic meanings...but even if you don't know the meanings of the symbols, it doesn't matter at all, the sculptures are just fascinating in themselves.

For me they are like a blending of baroque and Alice in Wonderland!!

As regards the exhibits there is a permanent collection of baroque and mannerist art, mainly religious in content. Undoubtedly good, but not really my cup of tea.  There are always exhibits of contemporary art, which in my opinion (please note I am not an artist or art critic) usually include at least several works of high quality and worth seeing.  

My 13 year old son was very impressed by the contemporary art exhibit and the patio.

I think it's worth paying a little extra to be able to take photos.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

151108268.name: Go For the Architecture, Stay for the Art
151108268.author: a TripAdvisor user
151108268.reviewBody: This well-preserved monastery would be a pleasure to explore, even if it were empty. It\'s not, though: it\'s full of remarkable art, from pre-Colombian stone artifacts to gory baroque religious sculpture, to frenetically carved tables and wardrobes, to local legal documents in heavily flourished script circa mid-19th century. The courtyards are gorgeous, and the views from the windows and balconies alone are worth the trip. Best free museum in Mexico, hands down.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

150524334.name: Great Experience
150524334.author: a TripAdvisor user
150524334.reviewBody: I just went today, and being an artist I am very picky about my time at art galleries. While their permanent collection is mostly made up of mannerist and baroque art, I felt they had beautiful examples. The art from Mexico was also very interesting. There were two contemporary exhibitions, one retrospective and another of a female Quereatro artist. I found both inspiring. My original career was in architecture so I have to say smething about the extraordinary structure. It\'s more than just an amazing building, but it lends itself to the art and the whole experience. Every time you come out of a gallery you get to experience the courtyard. I had a great time and well worth the 30 pesos (that\'s what $2.50)

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

148389005.name: Wonderful building with good exhibits
148389005.author: a TripAdvisor user
148389005.reviewBody: The builiding itself is delightful and worth a look. The exhibits were also very good, and were by two contemporary Mexican artisits. Also, we didn`t feel any need to pay to use a camera.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

146250530.name: Fascinating exhibits; gorgeous courtyard
146250530.author: a TripAdvisor user
146250530.reviewBody: We have never been disappointed with a museum in Mexico, and this was no exception. This museum would be worth visiting for its setting alone: in the the gorgeous courtyard of an old cloister of the church of San Agustin. The courtyard is packed  full of over-the-top ornamentation of angels and fantastic figures. The temporary exhibits were varied and excellently presented. The book store next door is small but with one of the best selections of books on Mexican art I\'ve seen anywhere.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

133875725.name: So so
133875725.author: a TripAdvisor user
133875725.reviewBody: The building is beautiful, but the artwork is average.  Some classical art and some modern in a weird format of indoor / outdoor rooms.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

130601005.name: A must see museum
130601005.author: a TripAdvisor user
130601005.reviewBody: Delightfully surprising in its depth of not only classic works, but also highly important modern Mexican artists.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

130434573.name: Beautiful building, but the artwork was unimpressive
130434573.author: a TripAdvisor user
130434573.reviewBody: Honestly I should admit that I\'ve never been a big fan of art museums.  However, I wanted to see the sights in Queretaro so I paid the 40 peso entry fee to check it out.  On the positive side, the building itself was gorgeous.  I enjoyed the architecture and the quiet courtyard inside.  The artwork itself .... well, I felt my 9 year old daughter could have done better paintings than a majority of the exhibits.  There were, however, some interesting religious paintings from the 17th and 18th centuries.  Otherwise, I found it a very average experience and would not go back.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

126288345.name: Amazing place!!!
126288345.author: a TripAdvisor user
126288345.reviewBody: This building is WOW.\nThe exhibitions might not turn out to be too attractive/luring. If you\'re lucky you might catch something worthy. The permanent exhibit is mainly made up of religious art.\nAll this being said... The building is worth the visit, the FINEST EXAMPLE of barroque architecture in THE CONTINENT. Try to get a guided visit or at least purchase a leaflet at the shop prior to entering. The building has very interesting stories to tell that also give you a parallel glimpse at Mexican History.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

124885929.name: viewing 16th and 17th art
124885929.author: a TripAdvisor user
124885929.reviewBody: The cost of entrance into the various museums is 30 to 40 pesos each. Walking through old town gives you the feeling that you are experiencing life hundreds of years before.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

121465375.name: Magnificent setting, magnificent art
121465375.author: a TripAdvisor user
121465375.reviewBody: I don\'t know that I can expand much on the title.  This is a must-see for any visitor to Queretaro.

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

120749342.name: Takes your breath away!
120749342.author: a TripAdvisor user
120749342.reviewBody: While the museum collection is itself very impressive, one isn\'t prepared for the sheer magnificience of the building it is housed in. The Cloister of the Temple of St. Augustine was built from 1731 -1736 in the Baroque style of the Colonial period. It\'s possible that the temperate climate of the area may have contributed to the pristine condition of the building as well as many others in the Centro Queretaro area.  A sight not to be missed!\n\nN.B.: Photos are not permitted of the building (this also may  help in ensuring structural integrity) but one can purchase an inexpensive fold-out, colour document called" Guia del Claustro".   It features key pictures as well as a brief overview of the history of the building. FYI: at this time, it is only published in Spanish but the pictures speak for themselves

address.streetAddress: Calle Ignacio Allende sur 14 Centro Historico

673094081.name: Not so much to see
673094081.author: a TripAdvisor user
673094081.reviewBody: This is a nice building,  not so well maintained and not so much to see. Maybe a concert if it happens to be in the area. The entrance is free of charge.

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

662311918.name: Not only a theater in its days\u2026
662311918.author: a TripAdvisor user
662311918.reviewBody:
Where the premiere of the Mexican National Anthem took place (1854) as well as the drafting of the Mexican Constitution (1916-1917).  One of the first buildings to get electricity in Queretaro.  In Maximilian's season it was left without a roof, because the original was made of zinc, a metal that was used to make bullets to fight the emperor. 
 
To me it has more the feel of a place of law than a place of art.  Rather dry and sober, not highly decorated but elegant.  Considering its history, it is understandable.  

Free admission.

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

613305878.name: Historical site
613305878.author: a TripAdvisor user
613305878.reviewBody: It is were it was signed the Mexican Constitution, but has a great historical value, as well as it has also a great Architecture

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

572512788.name: Lovely colonial building steeped in history.
572512788.author: a TripAdvisor user
572512788.reviewBody: This is where the Mexican national anthem was first sung and where Emporer Maximillian was tried and sentanced to death outside the old city centre (as in the famous Manet painting).

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

567431914.name: Took a tour
567431914.author: a TripAdvisor user
567431914.reviewBody: Tours are available and excellent in English. I just joined one that was just starting.  They built them to last.

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

483272611.name: Scenic
483272611.author: a TripAdvisor user
483272611.reviewBody: This place is full of history, and is very well preserved...\nIt\'s like a monument of the city, you must to take a tour for know the hole history.

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

448071905.name: Beautiful and intimate
448071905.author: a TripAdvisor user
448071905.reviewBody: The theater is intimate and perfect for a small orchestra or production. It is in the Centro Historico. Just walking around the area is a pleasure.

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

416576451.name: Very impressive
416576451.author: a TripAdvisor user
416576451.reviewBody: El Teatro is a beautifully preserved piece of history.  The names of the signers of the Constitution are engraved in gold on the wood backdrop.

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

404591544.name: Great history
404591544.author: a TripAdvisor user
404591544.reviewBody: You can\'t miss this place if you like to know everything about Mexico and how it\'s independence was this is a must spot you can hire a guide so you can know more about or read ahead. ( it gave me the chills when I\'m here )

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

342518350.name: Elegant
342518350.author: a TripAdvisor user
342518350.reviewBody:
This is the place where the actual Mexican Constitution was signed and now a days it not only serves political meetings, but also conferences and music concerets.

It is a neo classical construction with a European touch.

It is not very big and it is located in downtown.

If you see an event on going, don't hesitate to go inside and check it out.

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

341526975.name: Another gem for history buffs
341526975.author: a TripAdvisor user
341526975.reviewBody: The theater itself is quite nice.  It is hardly ever used.  If your visit to Queretaro is partly to visit the shrines of Mexican Independence, this is a must see.  Read ahead so that you can appreciate it.

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

314012973.name: It IS a theater although id does not look like it
314012973.author: a TripAdvisor user
314012973.reviewBody: This 150-year-old semi-colonial building stands on the corner of two side-streets just off one of Queretaro\'s main squares (jardin Zenea) and is one of the city\'s main theaters. Its position - on the crossing of two streets instead of a main square or wide avenue - is the first of the differences with most other theaters. The second difference is its outer architectural style, which makes it rather look like any other government or institutional building in Mexico. Its original name was Teatro de Iturbide; which was later changed into Teatro de la Republica. It can be visited, so you don\'t need to attend any specific function or representation to see its inside.

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

308612343.name: The place where Emperor Maximillian was condemned to death by firing squad
308612343.author: a TripAdvisor user
308612343.reviewBody: In my last visit last week I noticed that the  big plaques where they told the story of how in that theater a war council condemned to death by firing squad Emperor Maximillian had been removed. I ignore why.

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

306343084.name: Nice building
306343084.author: a TripAdvisor user
306343084.reviewBody: I didn\'t get inside this Teather but you can see that is very peculiar Mexican Design outside the building.\nNice place to check if you like historical art.

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

254876711.name: beautiful
254876711.author: a TripAdvisor user
254876711.reviewBody: is beautiful, in this place we have a lot of history, but you must be sure the day when you visit is open, normally is open only when they have some events, but consult with some guide.

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

244870618.name: Interesting historical site in the center of town
244870618.author: a TripAdvisor user
244870618.reviewBody: This structure, which is located a block north of the Jardin Zenea on Calle Ju\u00e1rez, dates back to the mid-19th century and was originally known as the Teatro Iturbide in honor of Mexico\u2019s first and brief-tenured Emperor.  In 1867, it served as the location for the trial of Maximilian (the second would-be Emperor) and his two senior generals who were charged with insurrection against the Nation.  They were found guilty and executed on the Cerro de las Campanas (for which see the Trip Advisor entry for the Hill of Bells).  In 1916-17 during the Mexican Revolution, the Teatro accommodated the Constitutional Congress that developed the document that still forms the basis of Mexican law.  The names of the members of the Congress appear on the wall behind the stage and a there is a room on the second floor of the building that commemorates this event with photos and historical information.  The Teatro is still used for musical presentations and civic occasions.

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

229999760.name: Important place to visiting Queretaro!!
229999760.author: a TripAdvisor user
229999760.reviewBody: Very interesting to see something authentic and traditional! The decor was original, impressive and would like to see it again!!  Spanish style and it\'s very famous for its decor and building.

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

192965787.name: Ornate colonial theater ... historically very important.
192965787.author: a TripAdvisor user
192965787.reviewBody:
Visited here in years past as well as well as on this last trip to QRO after eating brunch across the street at the Fin De Siglo ...

The place is beautiful and you can learn a lot about Mexican history ... as this was where the constitution was written.

Good for a nice tour.

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

185109182.name: Don\'t miss seeing this.
185109182.author: a TripAdvisor user
185109182.reviewBody: This where Emperor Maximillian was tried and convicted, and where the Mexican constitutional convention was held in 1917.  The theater is restored, and for some reason, was sold, I am told, to private interests. Still there are free performances there of the Queretaro chamber orchestra (which was the one we attended).

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

169801174.name: A place with history
169801174.author: a TripAdvisor user
169801174.reviewBody: The Teatro de la Republica is a famous spot, not because of the shows, acoustic or comfort of its seats, but because it was the site where the Mexican Constitution was signed on 1917. The place is well kept, but far from a couple of photo ops, if there\'s not a show in venue, there\'s no reason to visit beyond the lobby.

address.streetAddress: Juarez y Angela Peralta

163971090.name: interesting place to visit

Nevertheless is a good and cozy place to listen music.\n\nIt is one of the most elegant buildings in the city with a very sober decoration and a gravitas that only its historic relevance can confer.
